awd_titl_txt: Supporting Noyce Scholars Through Professional Learning Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Colorado at Colorado Springs (UCCS) will implement a Noyce Track 1 Scholarships & Stipends project to address the STEM teacher shortage across Southern Colorado, particularly in middle and high school classrooms serving economically and ethnically diverse student populations. This UCCS Noyce project will be providing financial support to approximately 35 talented and highly qualified undergraduate science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) content majors and post-baccalaureate STEM professionals simultaneously completing the requirements for a secondary education teaching license in mathematics or science through the UCCSTeach program. Upon graduation, Noyce graduates will be committing to teaching in a high-need school district for two years in return for each year of financial support received. Three high-need local education agencies (LEAs) will partner with UCCS to implement this Noyce project. Partnering LEAs include Colorado Springs School District 11, Falcon School District 49, and Harrison School District 2. Experienced in-service mentor teachers from STEM disciplines representing all three partner school districts and UCCS STEM faculty members will be supporting UCCS Noyce scholars throughout the duration of the project. This UCCS Noyce project will help reconcile the STEM teacher shortage in Southern Colorado by recruiting, training, and retaining high quality STEM graduates within high-need school districts. This project will be directly impacting between 10,000-12,000 secondary-level (grades 7-12) students enrolled in STEM courses over a five-year period. 

This UCCS Noyce project will include three distinct phases, with each phase implemented by UCCS STEM faculty in conjunction with experienced in-service mentor teachers from the partner LEAs. The project phases include: (1) strategic recruitment of a cohort of 7-10 Noyce candidates each year, (2) targeted pre-service STEM teacher training offered through the research-based UCCSTeach program, supplementary field experiences and pre-ternships, augmented by a series of Professional Learning Communities (PLCs) led by in-service mentor teachers from the partner LEAs, and (3) on-going support for in-service Noyce graduates through the creation of a Noyce Support Network. The project will be providing Noyce scholars with ongoing STEM content and teaching professional development opportunities, including both online and face-to-face offerings. This three-phase project will be resulting in the production of knowledgeable, highly-qualified STEM teachers who are well-prepared to effectively address the realities and challenges associated with teaching in high-need classrooms. The project will be systematically measuring the impact of the strategic recruitment efforts, efficacy of the pre-service teacher training (with a particular focus on impact and quality of the PLCs and in-service mentoring offered in phase 2), and outcomes associated with placement and retention of Noyce graduates as they relate to the Noyce Support Network.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: In 2017, the University of Colorado Colorado Springs (UCCS) was awarded a $1.2 million Noyce grant entitled "Supporting Noyce Scholars through Professional Learning Communities". This project provided scholarship support to undergraduate STEM majors (juniors or seniors), and post-baccalaureate STEM professionals pursuing initial teacher licensure in secondary mathematics or science (grades 7-12). Noyce scholarship recipients were awarded $15,000 per academic year and obligated to serve as a full-time STEM teacher in a high needs district for a total of two years for each year of scholarship support received. The project involved strategic partnerships with three local education agencies: Colorado Springs School District 11, Harrison School District 2, and Falcon School District 49.  This project accomplished three primary outcomes as outlined below.  

(1) Provided scholarship support: This project recruited talented undergraduate STEM majors and post-baccalaureate STEM professionals to pursue teaching careers in high needs school districts.  During the project period, a total of $645,000 in Noyce scholarship support was awarded to 32 unique individuals including 26 undergraduate STEM majors and 6 post-bacc STEM professionals seeking initial secondary mathematics or science licensure through the UCCSTeach program.  Additional scholarship outcomes are included below: 

Undergraduate statistics (26 unique Noyce scholars) 

  • 18/26 (69%) of undergraduate Noyce scholars successfully earned their initial secondary mathematics or science teaching license
  • 5/26 (19%) of undergraduate Noyce scholars are on track to earn their initial secondary mathematics or science teaching license in the 2023-2024 academic year 

  • 3/26 (12%) undergraduate Noyce scholars withdrew from the program for personal or medical reasons 

Post-baccalaureate statistics (6 unique Noyce scholars)

  • 5/6 (83%) of post-baccalaureate Noyce scholars successfully completed their initial mathematics or science teaching license 

  • 1/6 (17%) of post-baccalaureate Noyce scholars withdrew from the program for personal reasons

(2) Enhanced Teacher Training and Professional Development: This project incorporated several key components of training and professional development for all UCCS Noyce scholars. First, all Noyce scholars were enrolled in the UCCSTeach program, a secondary mathematics and science initial teacher licensure program.  The UCCSTeach program includes 33 credit hours of coursework in STEM education and over 800 hours of field work in mathematics or science classrooms. 

Second, the project introduced Professional Learning Communities (PLCs) as an integral part of the Noyce scholars' professional growth. The PLCs were designed and implemented by experienced in-service STEM teachers from the partner school districts and were strategically structured to complement the UCCSTeach program curriculum and enhance Noyce scholars' understanding of teaching and learning in high-needs educational settings. The 90-minute PLCs were conducted on a monthly basis during the academic year (August - May), covering various essential topics such as fostering student-teacher relationships, classroom management, assessment techniques, and grading strategies. 

In the initial three years of the program (from May 2017 to February 2020), the PLCs took place at UCCS and the partner local education agency (LEA) sites, rotating between different schools. This in person rotation model provided Noyce scholars with opportunities to interact with in-service teachers and administrators in high needs schools. During the 2020-2022 academic years, a blended approach was adopted, featuring both remote synchronous PLCs and a return to in-person PLCs for the remainder of the project period when COVID-19 restrictions allowed. 

In the third year, the project expanded its professional development initiatives by introducing a STEM Days of Summer Conference, hosted by UCCS. This conference was attended by Noyce scholars, in-service Noyce mentor teachers, and approximately 100 educators from across Colorado Springs and the Denver Metro region. 

(3) Strengthened the STEM Teacher Pipeline to High Needs Schools: A success of the UCCS project has been its significant impact on strengthening the pipeline of highly trained STEM teachers to high-needs schools.  To date, UCCS 23 Noyce scholars have completed their initial teacher licensure (18 undergraduates and 5 post-baccalaureate STEM professionals). 87% (20/23) of the UCCS Noyce scholars who completed the program have taught or are currently teaching in high-needs school districts. These scholars are making a meaningful difference in high-needs districts not only in Colorado but across the United States. UCCS Noyce alumni are now employed as secondary mathematics or science teachers in high-needs districts in various states, including Arkansas, Maine, Texas, and North Carolina.   

Summary: Overall, the UCCS project has been a successful and rewarding effort. The UCCS Noyce project provided financial support to pre-service STEM teacher candidates, expanded professional development opportunities in STEM education, and created a stronger pipeline to high needs school districts in Colorado and beyond.
